title: List of places of worship in Lewes District
data: Barcombe Cross 50°55′29″N 0°01′11″E / 50.9248°N 0.0196°E / 50.9248 ; 0.0196 ( Former St Francis of Assisi Church , Barcombe Cross )

The settlement of Barcombe Cross developed north of the old village . Squire of Barcombe Sir William Grantham provided built a timber and brick structure to serve it in the late 1890s . It went out of use in about 2003 , and is now used as a community hall and meeting place
Barcombe Cross 50°55′24″N 0°00′40″E / 50.9234°N 0.0110°E / 50.9234 ; 0.0110 ( Former Protestant Dissenters Mission House , Barcombe Cross )
This non-denominational mission chapel was established in the first half of the 19th century on the road from Barcombe Cross to Hamsey . It is no longer in religious use
Ditchling 50°55′20″N 0°06′51″W / 50.9222°N 0.1142°W / 50.9222 ; -0.1142 ( Former Beulah Strict Baptist Chapel , Ditchling )
George Grenyer built a chapel for the Strict Baptist community on East End Lane in 1867 . After its closure in the late 1930s it became a private house
East Blatchington 50°46′36″N 0°05′51″E / 50.7767°N 0.0975°E / 50.7767 ; 0.0975 ( Former St John the Evangelist 's Church , East Blatchington )

This church was built in the mid-1920s as a second church within the parish of East Blatchington , but closed in 1980 . It is now used as a nursery school . The building has a roughcast exterior and tiled roof
Laughton 50°54′26″N 0°07′44″E / 50.9073°N 0.1289°E / 50.9073 ; 0.1289 ( Former Laughton Methodist Chapel , Laughton )

This former chapel and the accompanying Sunday school and minister 's house have been converted into a house . It was built around 1879 on the road from Laughton to Shortgate . It was formally registered for marriages between 1934 and 1981
Lewes 50°52′21″N 0°00′48″E / 50.8724°N 0.0134°E / 50.8724 ; 0.0134 ( Former All Saints Church , Lewes )

This building - an accumulation of parts from several eras - has been used as an arts and community centre since its redundancy in 1975 . The 16th-century flint tower was retained when Amon Wilds built a new nave in 1806 ; an Early English-style chancel followed in 1883
Lewes 50°52′34″N 0°00′40″E / 50.8760°N 0.0112°E / 50.8760 ; 0.0112 ( Former Providence Baptist Chapel , Lewes )
This chapel is now a theatre auditorium . It closed in 1932 after about 70 years of religious use . The building , of blue and red brick , stands on Lancaster Street
Lewes 50°52′31″N 0°00′44″E / 50.8752°N 0.0121°E / 50.8752 ; 0.0121 ( Former Providence Strict Baptist Chapel , Lewes )

Opened with the name Gospel Temperance Mission Hall in 1906 , this Vernacular-style flint and brick building served as a Baptist chapel from 1924 until about 1980 , after which it was converted for residential use
Lewes 50°52′22″N 0°00′40″E / 50.8727°N 0.0110°E / 50.8727 ; 0.0110 ( Former Wesleyan Methodist Chapel , Lewes )

An 18th-century Countess of Huntingdon 's Connexion chapel stood on this site ; it was taken over by Methodists in 1807 and demolished in 1867 when the present building was built . The Early English-style red-brick and stone building was closed in 1973 and became an antiques centre
Lewes 50°52′27″N 0°00′42″E / 50.8741°N 0.0117°E / 50.8741 ; 0.0117 ( Former Hamilton Memorial Presbyterian Church , Lewes )
This large chapel , closed in the 1940s , has also become an antiques showroom and market . It is in the Renaissance style and is mostly of brick
Newhaven 50°47′30″N 0°02′57″E / 50.7918°N 0.0493°E / 50.7918 ; 0.0493 ( Former Calvinistic Baptist Chapel , Newhaven )
This was built in 1904 on the town 's Norman Road . The red-brick structure was distinguished by the Dutch gable on the façade . It was closed in 1976 and later became a house

After its closure in 1938 , this Neoclassical building was restored and turned into a market , but this has now closed . Horatio Nelson Goulty designed and built the rendered stone chapel in 1866 . It was not officially deregistered for worship until 1973
Newhaven 50°47′35″N 0°03′05″E / 50.7930°N 0.0513°E / 50.7930 ; 0.0513 ( Former Newhaven Methodist Church , Newhaven )

Charles Bell 's 1893 church for the Methodist community has become a Sea Cadets headquarters since its closure in 1940 . Yellow and red brick , stone and terracotta were used in the design . A rose window remains above the entrance
Newhaven 50°47′34″N 0°03′02″E / 50.7928°N 0.0506°E / 50.7928 ; 0.0506 ( Former Primitive Methodist Chapel , Newhaven )

Newhaven 's first Methodist chapel dates from 1885 . Architect W.S . Parnacott was commissioned ; his design was in the Gothic Revival style and incorporated a hall . It is no longer in religious use and has been significantly altered
Convent Chapel of the Sacred Heart
Newhaven 50°47′34″N 0°02′47″E / 50.7927°N 0.0463°E / 50.7927 ; 0.0463 ( Former Convent Chapel of the Sacred Heart , Newhaven )

Newhaven 's first Roman Catholic place of worship was designed in about 1878 by a French architect whose name does not survive in any records . It is Romanesque Revival in style and has an apsidal end and rendered walls . It fell out of use in about 1943 and was later used as a library and an arts centre
This modest brick-built chapel dates from 1834 . It has a large pediment , an entrance porch and a cemetery at the rear . In 2001 , planning permission was granted for conversion into flats
St Mary the Virgin Church/Church of Our Lady Queen of Heaven
North Chailey 50°58′20″N 0°01′18″W / 50.9721°N 0.0218°W / 50.9721 ; -0.0218 ( Former St Mary the Virgin Church/Church of Our Lady Queen of Heaven , North Chailey )

Built in 1876 in the 13th-century style by John Oldrid Scott , this chapel of ease to St Peter 's Church was used by Anglicans until 1976 , after which it was leased to the Catholic Church for about 20 years . It is now redundant and for sale . The sandstone building has a saddleback roof
Ringmer 50°53′38″N 0°03′35″E / 50.8940°N 0.0597°E / 50.8940 ; 0.0597 ( Former Rehoboth Independent Congregational Chapel , Ringmer )
The present red-brick building was converted into a house in 1995 . It dates from 1914 , and stands on the site of a predecessor which was built in 1834
South Heighton 50°48′27″N 0°03′28″E / 50.8074°N 0.0577°E / 50.8074 ; 0.0577 ( Former Congregational Chapel , South Heighton )
This small brick chapel in the village of South Heighton , now part of Newhaven , was erected in 1891 . It fell out of use in the mid-20th century and is now in residential use
Southover , Lewes 50°52′12″N 0°00′30″E / 50.8700°N 0.0082°E / 50.8700 ; 0.0082 ( Former Southover Baptist Chapel , Southover )

This chapel was converted into a house in 1972 after more than 200 years as a place of worship . It was built in 1741 as the first Baptist chapel in the Lewes area , and retains its knapped flintwork , original hipped roof and door , which has been reset in a modern weatherboarded porch
section_title: Closed or disused places of worship
